headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 8:15PM CDT by NWS Kansas City/Pleasant Hill MO
description:
At 814 PM CDT, emergency management reported a strong thunderstorm
near Albany, moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Emergency management.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is
possible.

Locations impacted include...
Bethany, Albany, New Hampton, and Martinsville.

This includes Interstate 35 in Missouri between mile markers 92 and
101.
areaDesc: Gentry; Harrison

headline: Freeze Warning issued October 17 at 7:41PM MDT until October 18 at 9:00AM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
description:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 23 expected.

* WHERE...Central Yampa River Basin, Upper Yampa River Basin, and
Animas River Basin.

* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 9 AM MDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other
sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor
plumbing.
areaDesc: Central Yampa River Basin; Upper Yampa River Basin; Animas River Basin

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 18 at 6:26PM CDT until October 18 at 7:15PM CDT by NWS Tulsa OK
description:
SVRTSA

The National Weather Service in Tulsa has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Northeastern Creek County in northeastern Oklahoma...
South central Tulsa County in northeastern Oklahoma...

* Until 715 PM CDT.

* At 626 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Sapulpa,
moving southeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Ping pong ball size hail and 60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail
damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect
wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations in or near the path include...
Mounds...                         Sapulpa...
Jenks...                          Glenpool...
Kiefer...                         Liberty...
Bixby...

This includes Interstate 44 between mile markers 206 and 214.
areaDesc: Creek, OK; Tulsa, OK

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 19 at 2:09PM EDT until October 20 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
description:
* WHAT...South winds 15 to 25 knots today becoming west 15 to 25
knots tonight through Monday.

* WHERE...The Lower Niagara River.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT Monday.

* IMPACTS...Winds and/or waves will cause hazardous conditions
that could capsize or damage small craft.
areaDesc: Lower Niagara River

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 19 at 2:09PM EDT until October 20 at 11:00PM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
description:
* WHAT...South winds to 30 knots today, becoming west to 30
knots tonight, then northwest to 30 knots Monday. Waves 7 to
10 feet.

* WHERE...The nearshore waters of Lake Erie from Ripley to
Buffalo.

* WHEN...Until 11 PM EDT Monday.

* IMPACTS...Winds and/or waves will cause hazardous conditions
that could capsize or damage small craft.
areaDesc: Ripley to Dunkirk NY; Dunkirk to Buffalo NY

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 19 at 2:09PM EDT until October 21 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
description:
* WHAT...South winds 15 to 25 knots today, west 15 to 25 knots
tonight, then northwest winds to 30 knots on Monday. Waves 10
to 13 feet on Monday.

* WHERE...The nearshore waters of Lake Ontario from the Niagara
River to Sodus Bay.

* WHEN...Until 5 AM EDT Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Winds and/or waves will cause hazardous conditions
that could capsize or damage small craft.
areaDesc: Niagara River to Hamlin Beach NY; Hamlin Beach to Sodus Bay NY

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 19 at 2:09PM EDT until October 21 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
description:
* WHAT...South winds 15 to 25 knots today, west winds 15 to 25
knots later tonight, then northwest winds to 30 knots Monday.
Waves 10 to 13 feet on Monday.

* WHERE...The nearshore waters of Lake Ontario from Sodus Bay to
Mexico Bay.

* WHEN...Until 8 AM EDT Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Winds and/or waves will cause hazardous conditions
that could capsize or damage small craft.
areaDesc: Sodus Bay to Mexico Bay NY

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 19 at 2:09PM EDT until October 21 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
description:
* WHAT...South winds to 30 knots today and tonight, then
northwest winds to 30 knots Monday. Waves 8 to 11 feet.

* WHERE...The nearshore waters of Lake Ontario from Mexico Bay
to the Saint Lawrence River.

* WHEN...Until 8 AM EDT Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Winds and/or waves will cause hazardous conditions
that could capsize or damage small craft.
areaDesc: Mexico Bay NY to the St. Lawrence River

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 19 at 2:09PM EDT until October 20 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
description:
* WHAT...South winds 15 to 25 knots today, west winds 15 to 25
knots tonight through Monday.

* WHERE...The Upper Niagara River and Buffalo Harbor.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT Monday.

* IMPACTS...Winds and/or waves will cause hazardous conditions
that could capsize or damage small craft.
areaDesc: Upper Niagara River and Buffalo Harbor

headline: Marine Weather Statement issued October 20 at 5:27PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
The areas affected include...
Offshore Caribbean Waters...
Mona Passage...

At 520 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated showers and thunderstorms,
capable of producing winds to around 30 knots. This activity is
associated with a Tropical Wave (AL98), which is being monitored
by the NHC. It is currently located well south of Puerto Rico and
the U.S. Virgin Islands. These thunderstorms are moving northeast
at 15 to 20 knots across the Caribbean waters to the Mona Passage.
areaDesc: Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico from 10 NM to 17N, including the Coastal Waters of Saint Croix; Mona Passage Southward to 17N

headline: The Tornado Warning has been cancelled.
description: The Tornado Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
areaDesc: Clark, AR; Garland, AR; Hot Spring, AR

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 19 at 4:23PM EDT until October 21 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
description:
* WHAT...South winds 15 to 25 kt with gusts up to 30 kt and seas
4 to 7 feet expected.

* WHERE...Coastal waters east of Ipswich Bay and the Stellwagen
Bank National Marine Sanctuary.

* WHEN...From 2 AM Monday to 5 AM EDT Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...Conditions will be hazardous to small craft.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Wind gusts may briefly approach gale
force at times Monday morning.
areaDesc: Coastal waters east of Ipswich Bay and the Stellwagen Bank National Marine Sanctuary

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 19 at 4:23PM EDT until October 21 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
description:

headline: High Surf Advisory issued October 20 at 9:46PM AST until October 21 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 10 to
14 feet. For the HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK, life-threatening rip
currents.

* WHERE... For the HIGH SURF ADVISORY, the most vulnerable areas
for high surf and beach erosion include Pinones along Road 187,
Parcelas Suarez, Villas del Mar, and Villa Christiana in Loiza;
Fortuna in Luquillo; Pueblo and Tamarindo in Aguadilla; Barrio
Obrero, Pueblo and Jarealito in Arecibo; Las Boca in
Barceloneta; Machuca in Manati; Puerto Nuevo in Vega Baja; Ocean
Park in San Juan; and Barrio Espinal in Aguada. For the HIGH
RIP CURRENT RISK, beaches along the northwest to northeast
coasts of the islands.

* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory now until 6 PM AST tuesday.
For the High Rip Current Risk remains through late tuesday
night.

* IMPACTS...FOR THE HIGH SURF ADVISORY, High waves that can wash
over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks.
Rough surf may also knock you down. Large breaking waves will
result in localized beach/dune structure erosion and dangerous
swimming conditions. FOR THE HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK, rip
currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into
deeper water, where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; North Central; Northwest; Mayaguez and Vicinity; Culebra; St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands

headline: Marine Weather Statement issued October 20 at 2:17PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
description:

Monday night. The direction and energy associated with this wave
group could bring higher than expected wave heights to Cross
Sound, Lisianski Strait, Inian Passes, and western Icy Strait.
Current forecast highlights west southwest swell of 15 to 22 ft at
15 to 18 seconds developing along Yakobi Island and Cape Spencer
Monday night. Caution is advised for mariners transiting Cross
Sound and western Icy Strait.

headline: High Surf Advisory issued October 18 at 4:24PM AST until October 20 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 10 to
14 feet. For the High Rip Current Risk, life-threatening rip
current.

* WHERE...For the High Surf Advisory, the most vulnerable areas
for high surf and beach erosion include Pinones along Road 187,
Parcelas Suarez, Villas del Mar, and Villa Christiana in Loiza;
Fortuna in Luquillo; Pueblo and Tamarindo in Aguadilla; Bario
Obrero, Pueblo and Jareaito in Arecibo; Las Boca in Barceloneta;
Machuca in Manati; Puerto Nuevo in Vega Baja; Ocean Park in San
Juan; and Barrio Espinal in Aguada. For the High Rip Current
Risk, beaches of northern Puerto Rico and Culebra.

* WHEN...For the High Rip Current Risk, now through Monday
afternoon. For the High Surf Advisory, from 6 AM Sunday to 6 PM
AST Monday.

* IMPACTS...For the High Surf Advisory, high waves that can wash
over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks. Rough
surf may also knock you down. Large breaking waves will result
in localized beach/dune structure erosion and dangerous swimming
conditions. For the High Rip Current Risk, rip currents can
sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water,
where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; North Central; Northwest; Mayaguez and Vicinity; Culebra

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 18 at 6:51PM CDT until October 18 at 7:30PM CDT by NWS Tulsa OK
description:
SVRTSA

The National Weather Service in Tulsa has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southwestern Wagoner County in northeastern Oklahoma...
Northeastern Okmulgee County in northeastern Oklahoma...
Northwestern Muskogee County in east central Oklahoma...
Southeastern Tulsa County in northeastern Oklahoma...

* Until 730 PM CDT.

* At 651 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 4 miles east of
Mounds, moving southeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Ping pong ball size hail and 60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail
damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect
wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations in or near the path include...
Preston...                        Stonebluff...
Hectorville...                    Haskell...
Bald Hill...                      Liberty...
Okmulgee...                       Bixby...
areaDesc: Muskogee, OK; Okmulgee, OK; Tulsa, OK; Wagoner, OK

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 19 at 6:35PM EDT until October 19 at 7:15PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
description:
SVRLWX

The National Weather Service in Sterling Virginia has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Northwestern Washington County in north central Maryland...
Northeastern Allegany County in western Maryland...
Northern Morgan County in the Panhandle of West Virginia...

* Until 715 PM EDT.

* At 635 PM EDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line
extending from Inglesmith to 6 miles southwest of Berkeley Springs,
moving east at 35 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Damaging winds will cause some trees and large branches
to fall. This could injure those outdoors, as well as
damage homes and vehicles. Roadways may become blocked by
downed trees. Localized power outages are possible.
Unsecured light objects may become projectiles.

* Locations impacted include...
Hancock, Berkeley Springs, Great Cacapon, Pecktonville, Forest
Park, Lineburg, Bellegrove, Berryville, Spohrs Crossroads, Sleepy
Creek, and Shady Grove.

headline: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 9:13PM EDT until October 18 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South
Carolina...

Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and
Marion Counties.

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.

* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.

* WHEN...Until Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect
residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of
Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding
becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 9:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 9.2 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage
early tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 6.7 feet
Tuesday evening.
- Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
- weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Horry, SC; Marion, SC

headline: Fire Weather Watch issued October 17 at 1:39PM MDT until October 19 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
description:

Watch for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect
Sunday afternoon.

* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 216, 239, 241, 246 and 247.

* TIMING...Sunday afternoon.

* WINDS...Southwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts 25 to 30 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...10 to 15%.

* IMPACTS...Conditions will be favorable for rapid fire spread.
Avoid outdoor burning and any activity that may produce a
spark and start a wildfire.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:48PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK

parts of the Interior. Most accumulations were on the order of 1

Saturday.

headline: Flood Warning issued October 17 at 8:58AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to
recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The
river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate
Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However,
tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.

For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is
forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:30 AM EDT Friday the stage was 3.2 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:30 AM EDT Friday was 3.3 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 3.2 feet today into early Saturday, falling slightly
to 3.1 feet this weekend.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: High Surf Advisory issued October 20 at 10:27AM AST until October 21 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory and Coastal Flood Advisory,
large breaking waves of 10 to 15 feet. For the High Rip
Current Risk, life-threatening rip current.

* WHERE...For the High Surf Advisory, the most vulnerable areas
for high surf, beach erosion and coastal flooding include
Pinones along Road 187, Parcelas Suarez, Villas del Mar, and
Villa Christiana in Loiza; Fortuna in Luquillo; Pueblo and
Tamarindo in Aguadilla; Barrio Obrero, Pueblo and Jareaito in
Arecibo; Las Boca in Barceloneta; Machuca in Manati; Puerto
Nuevo in Vega Baja; and Ocean Park in San Juan. For the High Rip
Current Risk, beaches of northern Puerto Rico.

* WHEN...For the High Rip Current Risk, through late tonight. For
the High Surf Advisory, through 6 AM AST Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...For the High Surf Advisory, high waves that can wash
over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks. Rough
surf may also knock you down. Large breaking waves will result
in localized beach/dune structure erosion and dangerous swimming
conditions. For the High Rip Current Risk, rip currents can
sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water,
where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; North Central; Northwest

headline: Flood Warning issued October 18 at 8:36PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to
recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The
river is forecast to remain steady or very slowly fall within
Moderate Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week.
However, tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.

For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is
forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued Sunday morning at 1000 AM EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 7:30 PM EDT Saturday the stage was 3.2 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 7:30 PM EDT Saturday was 3.2 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 3.2
feet just after midnight tonight.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 3:01PM PDT until October 18 at 12:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
description:
* WHAT...A moderate risk of sneaker waves.

* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on
beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These
waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly
pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious
injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping
anyone caught underneath.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will peak
during Friday evening, but seas will continue to build through
Saturday morning. After brief improvement Saturday night,
hazardous conditions due to high surf are possible late Sunday
into early Monday.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 8:14PM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves
expected in the surf zone.

* WHERE...The beaches north of Cape Hatteras.

* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT Saturday through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw
a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck
and back injuries.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 12:30 PM Saturday.

agency. They will relay your report to the National Weather Service

headline: Coastal Flood Advisory issued October 19 at 2:01PM EDT until October 19 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC

* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Warning, up to two feet of
inundation above ground level expected in low lying areas due to

half feet of inundation above ground level expected in low
lying areas due to tidal flooding.

* WHERE...Shoreline in Anne Arundel County.

* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Warning, until 8 PM EDT this
evening, especially around the time of high tide. For the

flooded. Compromise Street is flooded.

normal. The next high tide at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy is at
5:02 PM and 4:59 AM.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 19 at 9:49PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
description:
At 948 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking gusty showers along a line
extending from near Kings Dominion to Tuckahoe to 8 miles southeast
of Moseley. Movement was east at 40 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects.

These showers will be near...Richmond, Ashland, Virginia Union
University, Mechanicsville, Randolph Macon College, Chester,
Downtown Richmond, Bon Air, Virginia Commonwealth University, and
Hanover around 955 PM EDT.
Highland Springs around 1000 PM EDT.
Mangohick and Studley around 1005 PM EDT.
Beulahville around 1010 PM EDT.
Newtown, Manquin, Bottoms Bridge, and Aylett around 1015 PM EDT.
Tunstall around 1020 PM EDT.

Other locations impacted by these storms include Beazley, Wayside,
Gum Tree, Etna Mills, Montrose, Sandston, Glendale, Pocahontas State
Park, Biscoe, and Beach.
areaDesc: Caroline; Charles City; New Kent; Western Hanover; Eastern Hanover; Western Chesterfield; Eastern Chesterfield (Including Col. Heights); Western Henrico (Including the City of Richmond); Eastern Henrico; Western King William; Eastern King William; Western King and Queen; Western Essex

moving southeast at 30 mph.

damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

headline: Coastal Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 1:26PM EDT until October 16 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
description:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level
expected in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal
waterways.

* WHERE...Coastal Pender, Coastal New Hanover and Coastal
Brunswick Counties.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Low-lying roads and locations along the Intracoastal
Waterway and adjacent tidal creeks may observe minor coastal
flooding. Check with local officials for any road closures or

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Affected areas listed are based on
average tide conditions. Additional locations may experience
flooding during periods of heavy rainfall, high winds, or
other factors.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 20 at 9:06AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
description:
.Multiple rounds of heavy rain are possible for the panhandle this
week as a parade of systems move over the area. Locations primarily
impacted with the highest rain rates are expected to be the southern
half of the panhandle. First round of heavy rain is expected to
begin tonight and continue through Monday for the southern panhandle
with rain totals between 1.5 and 3.0 inches and rain rates
occasionally exceeding a tenth of an inch per hour. The second
system, arriving Tuesday, has a 60% chance for rain rates to exceed
one tenth of an inch per hour for 24 hours. Coinciding with the high
wind gusts is a 30% chance for rain rates to exceed 0.2 inches per
hour. Rain totals have an 80% chance to be between 1.5 and 3.5
inches. The third system late in the week has lower confidence but
higher potential, with totals between 1.5 and 4.5 inches. No
flooding is currently expected, but it is possible that rivers and
streams will rapidly rise with each round of precipitation.
areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

headline: Marine Weather Statement issued October 20 at 7:56PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
The areas affected include...
Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico from 10 NM to 17N...
Coastal Waters of Southern Puerto Rico out 10 NM...
Coastal Waters of Southwestern Puerto Rico out 10 NM...
Mona Passage Southward to 17N......

At 754 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated showers and thunderstorms,
capable of producing winds to around 30 knots. This activity is
associated with a Tropical Wave (AL98), which is being monitored
by the National Hurricane Center. It is moving westward south of
Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands tonight. These showers and
thunderstorms are moving west to northwest across the Caribbean
Waters to the Mona Passage at 15 to 20 knots.

headline: Wind Advisory issued October 18 at 9:53PM EDT until October 19 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS Jackson KY
description:
* WHAT...Southwest winds 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 40 mph
expected. Isolated gusts up to 45 mph are possible.

* WHERE...Portions of east central, south central, and southeast
Kentucky.

* WHEN...From 3 AM to 11 AM EDT Sunday.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around loose and poorly secured
objects, including holiday decorations. Tree limbs could be blown
down and a few power outages may result. Additionally, wet leaves
falling onto area roadways could lead to slick travel conditions.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The strongest winds will occur just ahead of
a frontal passage early to mid morning on Sunday. There will be
several hours of lighter winds late Sunday morning before winds
turn westerly and increase to 10 to 15 mph with gusts of 25 to 35
mph from mid afternoon Sunday through sunset, but gusts with this
second round of winds should remain below advisory thresholds.

headline: Flood Warning issued October 20 at 8:54PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to
past rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The river
is forecast to slowly fall through mid week. However, tide and wind
effects could periodically slow the decline, especially later this
week as northeasterly winds increase again.

For the St. Johns River...including Cocoa 9w, Above Lake Harney,
Sanford, Deland, Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued Tuesday morning at 1100 AM EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:30 PM EDT Monday the stage was 3.1 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:30 PM EDT Monday was 3.2 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 3.1
feet just after midnight tonight.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: High Surf Advisory issued October 17 at 2:15PM PDT until October 20 at 11:00AM PDT by NWS Medford OR
description:
* WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement. A moderate risk of
sneaker waves. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves
of 20-25 feet expected.

* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.

* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Saturday
morning. For the High Surf Advisory, from 11 AM Sunday to 11
AM PDT Monday.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on
beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These
waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly
pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious
injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping
anyone caught underneath. Large breaking waves will create
hazardous conditions along and within the surf zone, and could
inundate beaches and low lying shorelines. Beach erosion is
possible, and exposed infrastructure may be damaged.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will peak this
evening, but seas will continue to build through Saturday
morning and linger through the day Saturday. After brief
improvement Saturday night, hazardous conditions due to high
surf are expected late Sunday into early Monday with the highest
waves peaking out Sunday night.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

At 845 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking gusty showers along a line
extending from near Chase City to near Mint Hill. Movement was
southeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects.

Locations impacted include...
Raleigh, Durham, Cary, Chapel Hill, Burlington, Sanford, Asheboro,
Albemarle, Henderson, and Graham.

This includes the following highways...
Interstate 85 between Mile Markers 163 and 233.
Interstate 40 between Mile Markers 134 and 162, and between Mile
Markers 259 and 286.
Interstate 540 between Mile Markers 0 and 9.
US 1 between Mile Markers 69 and 85.
the Durham Freeway between Mile Markers 2 and 17.
Interstate 73 between Mile Markers 26 and 88.
areaDesc: Person; Granville; Vance; Warren; Guilford; Alamance; Orange; Durham; Franklin; Davidson; Randolph; Chatham; Wake; Stanly; Montgomery; Moore; Lee; Anson; Richmond

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 19 at 4:23PM EDT until October 19 at 4:45PM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
description:
At 422 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Neola, moving
northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...
Lewisburg...
White Sulphur Springs...
Ronceverte...
Renick...
Warm Springs...
Neola...
and Hot Springs.

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 18 at 4:48PM CDT until October 18 at 5:45PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
description:
SVRSHV

The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southwestern Bienville Parish in northwestern Louisiana...
Northwestern Natchitoches Parish in northwestern Louisiana...
Red River Parish in northwestern Louisiana...

* Until 545 PM CDT.

* At 448 PM CDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line from
9 miles west of Coushatta to 8 miles east of Coushatta, or along a
line from 12 miles east of Mansfield to 19 miles north of
Natchitoches, moving north at 35 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind
damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Coushatta, Ringgold, Martin, Hall Summit, Lucky, Ashland, Castor,
Edgefield, Jamestown, Powhatan, Womack, Crichton, Loggy Bayou,
Armistead, Hanna, Grand Bayou, Lake End and Lake Bistineau South.
areaDesc: Bienville, LA; Natchitoches, LA; Red River, LA

seconds and north winds 10 to 15 kt, shifting south 15 to 25 kt
with gusts up to 30 kt after 1100 Saturday.

* WHERE...In the Main Channel of the Columbia River Bar.

* WHEN...From 5 PM this afternoon to 5 AM PDT Sunday.

10 to 12 ft. Ebb current of 4.67 kt at 335 PM Saturday. Seas

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 5:54AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
description:
Fine fuels remain very dry across Vermont according to the
Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation. This,
combined with gusty northerly winds of 25 to 30 MPH and relative
humidity as low as 35%, may have an impact on fire weather
conditions. If any fires were to start the weather and fuel
conditions could cause fires to quickly get out of control and be
difficult to contain.

For more information about the current fire danger rating, any burn
restrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit
your state forestry or environmental protection website. Remember, a
debris burn ban is in effect for all of Vermont which means no
open burning of debris is allowed.
areaDesc: Western Chittenden; Western Addison; Orange; Western Rutland; Eastern Addison; Eastern Rutland; Western Windsor; Eastern Windsor

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 5:54AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT

quickly get out of control and be difficult to contain.

visit the New York State forestry or environmental protection
website.

heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 2 inches of
rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are
possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected
to begin shortly.

HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban
areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as
other poor drainage and low-lying areas.

* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...
mainly rural areas of Northwestern Reeves County

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 2:13AM PDT until October 18 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.

* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South
Washington Coast.

* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach
than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves
can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull
them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or
drowning.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when
sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions
in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the
water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially
watchful of children.

possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways
resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low
lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes
adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding.
Portions of NC-12 may be impacted with ocean overwash around
high tide. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a
swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and
back injuries.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 10:30 am this morning.

headline: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 3:15PM CDT until October 16 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive
rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...Portions of northwest Kansas, including the following
county, Rawlins and southwest Nebraska, including the following
counties, Hitchcock and Red Willow.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM CDT.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 314 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to
thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream
flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen.
- Additional rainfall amounts up to 1.5 inches are expected
over the area. This additional rain will result in minor
flooding.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
McCook, Atwood, Herndon, Ludell and Blakeman.

SVRJAN

The National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southeastern Washington County in northwestern Mississippi...
Humphreys County in central Mississippi...
Northern Sharkey County in west central Mississippi...

* Until 930 PM CDT.

* At 826 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Nitta Yuma,
or 9 miles north of Rolling Fork, moving northeast at 50 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* This severe thunderstorm will be near...
Hollandale, Delta City, and Murphy around 830 PM CDT.
Midnight around 840 PM CDT.
Belzoni, Isola, and Silver City around 845 PM CDT.
areaDesc: Humphreys, MS; Sharkey, MS; Washington, MS

headline: Tornado Warning issued October 18 at 3:09PM CDT until October 18 at 4:00PM CDT by NWS Little Rock AR
description:
TORLZK

The National Weather Service in Little Rock has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
Central Clark County in southwestern Arkansas...

* Until 400 PM CDT.

* At 308 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Beirne, or 10 miles northeast of Prescott, moving
northeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* Locations impacted include...
Arkadelphia...                    Gurdon...
Caddo Valley...                   Beirne...
Gum Springs in Clark County...    Richwoods...
Burtsell...                       Lower Lake Recreation Area...
Curtis...                         Griffithtown...
Dalark...

The National Weather Service in Memphis has issued a

Northern Fayette County in west Tennessee...
Northwestern Hardeman County in west Tennessee...
Haywood County in west Tennessee...
Southwestern Madison County in west Tennessee...

Mercer, Warren, Oakland, Stanton, Williston, Toone, Braden, and

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 6:42AM PDT by NWS Elko NV
description:
Patchy fog will continue across portions of northern Nevada,
specifically Humboldt, northern Lander/Eureka, and Elko counties
this morning. Satellite imagery and remote sensing platforms show
patchy fog in various locations across Interstate 80, US Highway
93 and 95, and various State Routes in these areas with
reductions to visibility of one mile or less in spots. Motorists
are urged to use caution when driving along these and other
roadways as rapid changes to visibility are likely this morning.
Please use low beams and reduce speeds to arrive safely to your
destination.

Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.
areaDesc: Humboldt County; Northern Lander County and Northern Eureka County

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:49PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
description:
A couple waves of energy will bring the potential for snow squalls
Saturday through Sunday night. Squalls are notoriously quick in
nature, but can bring brief heavy bursts of snow and wind gusts up
to 35 mph which can reduce visibility below 1 mile at times. Snow
accumulations of 1 to 3 inches is possible, with the heaviest
expected in the Western Seward Peninsula and most of it coming
Saturday night through Sunday.
areaDesc: Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; St Lawrence Island

headline: Marine Weather Statement issued October 17 at 7:11PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
The areas affected include...
Atlantic Waters of Puerto Rico AND USVI from 10 NM to 19.5N...

At 706 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated a strong thunderstorm, capable
of producing winds to around 30 knots. This thunderstorm was located
over the northern offshore Atlantic waters, moving northeast at 15
to 20 knots. A line of strong thunderstorms is also just outside the
local offshore Atlantic waters, north of 19.5N, moving southeast at
around 15 to 20 knots and capable of producing winds to around 30
knots.

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 3:22AM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an
increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast
Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

headline: Flood Warning issued October 17 at 10:13AM EDT until October 18 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South
Carolina...

Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and
Marion Counties.

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.

* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.

* WHEN...Until tomorrow morning.

* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect
residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of
Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding
becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 10:00 AM EDT Friday the stage was 9.1 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage
this afternoon and continue falling to 6.1 feet Wednesday
morning.
- Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
- weather.gov/safety/flood

headline: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 16 at 2:32AM EDT until October 17 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
description:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.

* WHERE...Florida Keys.

* WHEN...Through late tonight.

* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets
and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some
seawalls and docks will be overtopped. In the Lower and Middle
Keys, minor flooding will be most pronounced around the time
of high tide. In the Upper Keys, little relief is expected,
even outside the windows of high tide. Boaters can expect less
clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that
persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost
certain to contain a mix of saltwater.
areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

headline: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 16 at 3:59PM EDT until October 17 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
description:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.

* WHERE...Florida Keys.

* WHEN...Through late tonight.

* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets
and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some
seawalls and docks will be overtopped. In the Lower and Middle
Keys, minor flooding will be most pronounced around the time
of high tide. In the Upper Keys, little relief is expected,
even outside the windows of high tide. Boaters can expect less
clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that
persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost
certain to contain a mix of saltwater.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

headline: Red Flag Warning issued October 19 at 12:24PM MDT until October 20 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
...Critical Fire Weather Conditions Forecast on Monday...

Strong northwest winds will develop in the wake of a cold frontal
passage Monday morning. Strong winds will persist through the
afternoon, when relative humidity readings are forecast to fall
into the mid-teens. Blowing dust may accompany the winds through
the day as well.

The National Weather Service in Goodland has issued a Red Flag
Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect
from 11 AM to 6 PM MDT Monday. The Fire Weather Watch is no
longer in effect.

* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 252 Yuma, 253 Kit Carson
and 254 Cheyenne.

* TIMING...From 11 AM to 6 PM MDT Monday.

* WINDS...Northwest 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 55 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 14 percent.

* IMPACTS...Unpredictable fire behavior. Any fires that develop
may rapidly grow and spread out of control.
areaDesc: Yuma; Kit Carson County; Cheyenne

description:
Offshore waters forecast for Gulf of Alaska east of 144W

Wind forecasts reflect the predominant speed and direction
expected. Sea forecasts represent the average of the highest
one-third of the combined windwave and swell height.

.TONIGHT...NW wind 35 kt. Seas 14 ft. Rain showers early in the
evening. Slight chance of thunderstorms in the evening.
.SUN...W wind 25 kt. Seas 10 ft. Rain in the afternoon.
.SUN NIGHT...S gale to 35 kt. Seas 11 ft building to 14 ft
late. Rain.
.MON...E gale to 40 kt becoming W in the afternoon. Seas
22 ft. Showers.
.MON NIGHT...W gale to 35 kt. Seas 20 ft. Showers.
.TUE...S gale to 35 kt. Seas 14 ft.
.WED...S wind 20 kt. Seas 13 ft.
.THU...W wind 20 kt. Seas 11 ft.
areaDesc: Gulf of Alaska South of 57 Degrees North and East of 144 W

headline: High Surf Advisory issued October 18 at 9:04PM EDT until October 19 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC

* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 6
to 9 feet in the surf zone. For the Beach Hazards Statement,
dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves expected in
the surf zone.

* WHERE...Hatteras Island beaches.

* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 8 AM EDT Sunday. For
the Beach Hazards Statement, from 8 AM EDT Sunday through
Sunday evening.

* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and
localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best
swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore
break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom
causing neck and back injuries.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 1 PM Saturday.

expected in the surf zone.

* WHERE...Northern Outer Banks beaches.

* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT Sunday through Sunday evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw
a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck
and back injuries.

currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 1 PM Sunday.

17N...

producing waterspouts was located mainly over areas of the Anegada
Passage, moving northeast at 15 knots.

higher winds and suddenly higher waves.

headline: Tornado Warning issued October 16 at 4:50PM MDT until October 16 at 5:15PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
At 450 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 10 miles north of Burlington, moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
northeastern Kit Carson County.

This includes Highway 385 between mile markers 196 and 206, and near
mile marker 211.
areaDesc: Kit Carson, CO

Tenaha, or 10 miles southeast of Carthage, moving east at 35 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and half dollar size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage

Logansport, Tenaha, Joaquin, Longstreet, Paxton and Woods.

Bixby...

downpours. Make sure all on board are wearing life
jackets.

Tarpon Springs, Port Richey, Bayport, and Dunedin.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 19 at 1:04PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
description:
.Multiple rounds of heavy rain are possible for the panhandle this
week as a parade of systems move over the area. Locations primarily
impacted with the highest rain rates are expected to be the southern
half of the panhandle. First round of heavy rain is expected to
begin tonight and continue through Monday for the southern panhandle
with rain totals between 1.5 and 3.0 inches and rain rates
occasionally exceeding a tenth of an inch per hour. The second
system, arriving Tuesday, has a 60% chance for rain rates to exceed
one tenth of an inch per hour for 24 hours. Coinciding with the high
wind gusts is a 30% chance for rain rates to exceed 0.2 inches per
hour. Rain totals have an 80% chance to be between 1.5 and 3.5
inches. The third system late in the week has lower confidence but
higher potential, with totals between 1.5 and 4.5 inches. No
flooding is currently expected, but it is possible that rivers and
streams will rapidly rise with each round of precipitation.
areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

At 317 PM CDT, trained weather spotters reported funnel clouds
associated with a cluster of showers from near Ladd into parts of
western La Salle County. Additional showers with a potential for
funnel clouds will be possible from near Somonauk to 6 miles
southeast of Mendota to DePue. Shower movement was northeast at 20
mph.

HAZARD...Funnel clouds.

SOURCE...Trained weather spotters.

IMPACT...Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible. Gusty winds
could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured
objects.

Locations impacted include...
Sandwich, Prairie Center, Somonauk, Leland, Earlville, Triumph,
Harding, Troy Grove, Lake Holiday, Peru, and La Salle.
areaDesc: De Kalb; La Salle

headline: Special Marine Warning issued October 20 at 5:20PM EDT until October 20 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
description:
SMWCAR

The National Weather Service in Caribou Maine has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Intra Coastal Waters from Schoodic Point, ME to Stonington, ME...

* Until 600 PM EDT.

* At 520 PM EDT, showers were located along a line extending from 22
nm north of Islesboro to 20 nm southwest of Great Duck Island
Light, moving east at 25 knots.

HAZARD...Wind gusts 34 knots or greater.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Small craft could be damaged in briefly higher winds and
suddenly higher waves.

* Locations impacted include...
Stonington.
areaDesc: Intra Coastal Waters from Schoodic Point, ME to Stonington, ME

headline: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 3:46PM EDT until October 18 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South
Carolina...

Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and
Marion Counties.

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.

* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.

* WHEN...Until Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect
residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of
Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding
becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 3:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 9.1 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage
early tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 7.3 feet
Tuesday morning.
- Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
- weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Horry, SC; Marion, SC

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 16 at 6:44PM CDT until October 16 at 6:45PM CDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
The Severe Thunderstorm Warning that was previously in effect has
been reissued for Cheyenne county until 7:45 PM CT. Please refer to
that bulletin for the latest severe weather information.

To report severe weather, contact your nearest law enforcement
agency. They will relay your report to the National Weather Service
Goodland.

Remember, a Severe Thunderstorm Warning still remains in effect for
Cheyenne county until 7:45 PM CT.
areaDesc: Cheyenne, KS

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Watch issued October 18 at 6:12PM CDT until October 19 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Memphis TN

headline: Marine Weather Statement issued October 18 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
description:
A Marine Weather Statement has been issued for the following areas...

Nearshore Waters from Northerly Island to Calumet Harbor...
Nearshore Waters from Calumet Harbor to Burns Harbor...
Open Waters from Wilmette Harbor to Michigan City out to Mid
Lake...

At 700 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated strong thunderstorms, capable
of producing winds to around 30 knots and small hail. These
thunderstorms were located along a line extending from near Calumet
Harbor to near Indiana Harbor, moving northeast at 20 knots.
areaDesc: Northerly Island to Calumet Harbor IL; Calumet Harbor IL to Gary IN; Gary to Burns Harbor IN; Lake Michigan from Wilmette Harbor to Michigan City in 5NM offshore to Mid Lake

headline: Wind Advisory issued October 19 at 5:33PM EDT until October 20 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
description:
* WHAT...West winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.

* WHERE...In Virginia, Western Highland County. In West Virginia,
Western Grant and Western Pendleton Counties.

* WHEN...Until 8 AM EDT Monday.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree
limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.
areaDesc: Western Highland; Western Grant; Western Pendleton

headline: Freeze Warning issued October 16 at 1:11PM EDT until October 17 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Albany NY
description:
* WHAT...A widespread frost with temperatures at or below 32 degrees.

* WHERE...Northern Saratoga, Washington, and Southeast Warren
Counties.

* WHEN...From 11 PM this evening to 10 AM EDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other
sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor
plumbing.
areaDesc: Northern Saratoga; Northern Washington; Southeast Warren; Southern Washington

headline: Frost Advisory issued October 16 at 1:11PM EDT until October 17 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Albany NY
description:
* WHAT...Areas of frost formation due to low temperatures ranging
widely from 33 to 36 degrees.

* WHERE...In Connecticut, Northern Litchfield County. In New York,
Eastern Albany, Eastern Dutchess, Eastern Greene, Eastern
Schenectady, Eastern Ulster, Southern Saratoga, Western Columbia,
Western Dutchess, and Western Rensselaer Counties.

* WHEN...From 11 PM this evening to 10 AM EDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive
outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.
areaDesc: Northern Litchfield; Eastern Schenectady; Southern Saratoga; Eastern Albany; Western Rensselaer; Eastern Greene; Western Columbia; Eastern Ulster; Western Dutchess; Eastern Dutchess

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 18 at 3:25PM CDT until October 18 at 4:30PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
description:
At 325 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 8 miles north of
Lewisville, moving northeast at 35 mph.

HAZARD...Ping pong ball size hail and 60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail
damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect
wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...
Lewisville, Rosston, Willisville, Bodcaw, Bluff City, Cale,
Patmos, Mount Moriah, Sutton, Laneburg, Waterloo, Falcon, Morris,
Young and Piney Grove.
areaDesc: Hempstead, AR; Lafayette, AR; Nevada, AR

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 4:52AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
description:
A couple waves of energy will bring the potential for snow squalls
Saturday through Sunday night. Squalls are notoriously quick in
nature, but can bring brief heavy bursts of snow and wind gusts up
to 35 mph which can reduce visibility below 1 mile at times. Snow
accumulations of 1 to 3 inches is possible, with the heaviest
expected in the Western Seward Peninsula and most of it coming
Saturday night through Sunday.
areaDesc: Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; St Lawrence Island

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 5:51PM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
description:
* WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents,
large breaking waves, and strong longshore currents in the surf
zone. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to 1 to 2 feet of
inundation above ground level in low- lying areas near
shorelines and tidal waterways.

* WHERE...Hatteras Island.

* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Friday
evening. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 8 PM EDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is
possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways
resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low
lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes
adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding.
Portions of NC-12 may be impacted with ocean overwash around
high tide. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a
swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and
back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous
swimming conditions.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 11:30 AM Friday.
areaDesc: Hatteras Island

headline: Freeze Watch issued October 17 at 1:49PM CDT until October 19 at 11:00AM CDT by NWS Hastings NE
description:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 28 possible.

* WHERE...Greeley, Sherman, Valley, Buffalo, Dawson, Furnas, Gosper,
and Phelps Counties.

* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Sunday morning.

* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other
sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor
plumbing.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Clearing skies and diminishing winds will
allow temperatures to rapidly fall across the region Saturday
evening, with sub-freezing temperatures becoming possible late
Saturday night through Sunday morning.
areaDesc: Valley; Greeley; Sherman; Dawson; Buffalo; Gosper; Phelps; Furnas

Bixby...                          Tulsa...

headline: Heavy Freezing Spray Warning issued October 17 at 4:00PM AKDT until October 18 at 5:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
description:
Offshore Waters Forecast for the US Arctic Waters

Sea forecasts represent an average of the highest one-third of
the combined wind wave and swell height. Individual waves may be
twice as high.

.TONIGHT...E winds 25 kt. Seas 8 ft. Heavy freezing spray.
.SAT...E winds 25 kt. Seas 7 ft. Heavy freezing spray.
.SAT NIGHT...E winds 25 kt. Seas 7 ft. Heavy freezing spray.
.SUN...E winds 20 kt. Seas 6 ft. Heavy freezing spray.
.SUN NIGHT...E winds 15 kt. Seas 5 ft. Heavy freezing spray.
.MON...NE winds 15 kt. Seas 5 ft.
.TUE...NE winds 15 kt. Seas 4 ft.
.WED...NE winds 20 kt. Seas 5 ft.
areaDesc: Central US Arctic Offshore

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 2:16PM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an
increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast
Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

headline: Dust Storm Warning issued October 20 at 12:12PM CDT until October 20 at 1:45PM CDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
The National Weather Service in Goodland has issued a

* Dust Storm Warning for...
Eastern Logan County in west central Kansas...
Southwestern Gove County in west central Kansas...

* Until 145 PM CDT.

* At 1210 PM CDT, a dust channel was near the intersection of
Highways 25 and 40 west of Oakley, extending southeast to near
Monument Rocks.

HAZARD...Less than a quarter mile visibility with wind in excess
of 50 mph.

SOURCE...Emergency Management.

IMPACT...Dangerous life-threatening travel.

* Highways 25, 40 and 83 in Logan County.

Locations impacted include...
Monument and The Monument Rocks.
areaDesc: Gove, KS; Logan, KS

headline: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 1:50AM MDT until October 16 at 3:15AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
description:
* WHAT...Arroyo and small stream flooding caused by excessive
rainfall continues.

* WHERE...A portion of north central New Mexico, including the
following counties, Los Alamos, south central Rio Arriba and
northwestern Santa Fe.

* WHEN...Until 315 AM MDT.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
Water over roadways. Overflowing poor drainage areas.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 149 AM MDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to
training thunderstorms. This will cause arroyo and small
stream flooding. Between 1 and 1.5 inches of rain have
fallen.
- Additional rainfall amounts of 0.25 to 0.5 inches are
expected over the area. This additional rain will result in
minor flooding.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Los Alamos, Espanola, White Rock, Santa Clara Pueblo,
Bandelier National Monument, San Ildefonso Pueblo, Hernandez
and Chili.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Los Alamos, NM; Rio Arriba, NM; Santa Fe, NM

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 2:10PM PDT until October 18 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.

* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South
Washington Coast.

* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach
than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves
can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull
them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or
drowning.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when
sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions
in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the
water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially
watchful of children.
areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 3:40AM PDT by NWS Elko NV

Lander/Eureka counties this morning. Satellite imagery and remote
sensing platforms show patchy fog with visibility dropping to one
mile or less in spots. Locations and roads being affected are US
Highway 95 from Winnemucca north to Paradise Valley, I-80 from the
Humboldt/Pershing county line east to Battle Mountain, and Jungo
road from Antelope Summit to Winnemucca. Motorists are urged to
use caution when driving along these and other roadways as rapid
changes to visibility are likely this morning.

Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.

a line extending from near Lovelaceville to Fulton. Movement was
northeast at 35 mph.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects.

Mayfield, Lynnville, Sedalia, Wingo, Water Valley, Lowes, Fancy Farm,
Dukedom, and Symsonia.

This includes Interstate 69 in Kentucky between Mile Markers 9 and
33.

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 18 at 8:13PM CDT until October 18 at 9:15PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
description:
SVRSHV

The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southwestern De Soto Parish in northwestern Louisiana...
Northeastern Shelby County in eastern Texas...
Southern Panola County in northeastern Texas...

* Until 915 PM CDT.

* At 813 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 8 miles southwest
of Carthage, moving east at 35 mph.

HAZARD...Ping pong ball size hail and 60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect
hail damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles.
Expect wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Carthage, Logansport, Tenaha, Joaquin, Gary City, Longstreet,
Woods and Paxton.

headline: Gale Warning issued October 20 at 3:40PM AKDT until October 22 at 5:00AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
description:
Offshore waters forecast for the Gulf of Alaska West of 144W

Wind forecasts reflect the predominant speed and direction
expected. Sea forecasts represent an average of the highest
one-third of the combined wind wave and swell height.

.TONIGHT...W wind up to 15 kt. Seas 9 to 17 ft. Rain showers.
.TUE...SE wind 10 to 25 kt. Seas 6 to 11 ft. Rain.
.TUE NIGHT...NE wind 20 to 35 kt. Seas 8 to 13 ft building to 11 to
19 ft after midnight. Rain.
.WED...N wind 10 to 25 kt. Seas 13 to 21 ft.
.WED NIGHT...SE wind up to 20 kt. Seas 9 to 16 ft.
.THU THROUGH SAT...E wind up to 20 kt. Seas 8 to 13 ft.
areaDesc: Gulf of Alaska Offshore North of 57N and West of 144W

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 20 at 6:26PM PDT until October 22 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A moderate to long period northwesterly swell will result
in breaking waves of 12 to 17 feet and an increased risk for
sneaker waves and rip currents. Waves locally up to 20 feet at
favored breaking points.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay, Southern Monterey Bay, and Big Sur Coast.

* WHEN...Through Wednesday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The largest breaking waves will be Tuesday
night and into Wednesday where favored locations such as
Mavericks may exceed 20 feet.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

headline: High Surf Advisory issued October 20 at 8:45AM PDT until October 22 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
description:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 10 to 14 feet with dangerous
rip currents due to a moderate to long period northwest swell.

* WHERE...San Luis Obispo County Beaches and Santa Barbara
County Central Coast Beaches.

* WHEN...Until 9 PM PDT Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip
currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large
breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and
rocks, and capsize small boats near shore.

headline: Rip Current Statement issued October 19 at 4:08PM AST until October 21 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory and Coastal Flood Advisory,
large breaking waves of 10 to 15 feet. For the High Rip Current
Risk, life-threatening rip current.

* WHERE...For the High Surf Advisory and Coastal Flood Advisory,
the most vulnerable areas for high surf, beach erosion and
coastal flooding include Pinones along Road 187, Parcelas
Suarez, Villas del Mar, and Villa Christiana in Loiza; Fortuna
in Luquillo; Pueblo and Tamarindo in Aguadilla; Barrio Obrero,
Pueblo and Jareaito in Arecibo; Las Boca in Barceloneta; Machuca
in Manati; Puerto Nuevo in Vega Baja; and Ocean Park in San
Juan. For the High Rip Current Risk, beaches of northern Puerto
Rico.

* WHEN...For the High Rip Current Risk, through late Monday night.
For the High Surf Advisory and the Coastal Flood Advisory,
through 6 PM AST Monday.

* IMPACTS...For the High Surf Advisory, high waves that can wash
over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks.
Rough surf may also knock you down. Large breaking waves will
result in localized beach/dune structure erosion and dangerous
swimming conditions. For the High Rip Current Risk, rip
currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into
deeper water, where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
For the Coastal Flooding, minor to moderate coastal flooding
is possible during the high tides, particularly along
low-lying and vulnerable coastal areas.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The next high tide for San Juan is 1.33
feet at 7.32 PM AST. The next high tide for Aguadilla is 1.30
ft at 7:01 PM AST. The next high tide for Fajardo is 1.30 ft
at 7:27 PM AST.
areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; North Central; Northwest

headline: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 9:48AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to
recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The
river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate
Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However,
tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.

For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is
forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 3.3 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:30 AM EDT Thursday was 3.3 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 3.2 feet through late week, falling to 3.1 feet this
weekend.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: Flood Warning issued October 19 at 8:41PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage. The
river fluctuated slightly higher this evening as storms moved over
Lake George. However, the water level is returning back closer to
the ongoing trends, and a slow decline to around 3 feet, or just
within Moderate Flood Stage, is forecast through the work week.

For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is
forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued Monday morning at 1000 AM EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 7:30 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 3.1 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 7:30 PM EDT Sunday was 3.3 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 3.1 feet.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 20 at 12:20PM PDT until October 22 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A moderate to long period northwesterly swell will result
in breaking waves of 15 to 20 feet and an increased risk for
sneaker waves and rip currents.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay, Southern Monterey Bay, and Big Sur Coast.

* WHEN...Through Wednesday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The largest breaking waves will be Tuesday
night and into Wednesday where favored locations such as
Mavericks may reach up to or exceed 25 feet.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 4:12PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
description:
At 412 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 7
miles northwest of Stonewall, or 9 miles southwest of Shreveport,
moving northeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and pea size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.

Locations impacted include...
Shreveport, Bossier City, Greenwood, Stonewall, Fosters, Eastwood,
Keachi, Forbing, Keithville, Robson, Barksdale Air Force Base,
Taylortown, Ferguson, Sligo, Spring Ridge, Bodcau and Red Chute.

headline: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 8:55PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to
recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The
river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate
Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However,
tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.

For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is
forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued Friday afternoon at noon EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 3.2 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:30 PM EDT Thursday was 3.3 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 3.2 feet.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: Frost Advisory issued October 16 at 2:05PM MDT until October 17 at 9:00AM MDT by NWS Boise ID
description:
* WHAT...Temperatures 33 to 36 will result in frost formation.

* WHERE...Western Magic Valley and Upper Treasure Valley east of
Boise.

* WHEN...From 3 AM to 9 AM MDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive
outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Frost is not expected within the Boise Metro

temperatures early next week may result in more widespread frost
or freezing temperatures.

headline: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 4:07AM AST until October 16 at 6:30AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive
rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...Guayanilla, Penuelas and Yauco.

* WHEN...Until 630 AM AST.

* IMPACTS...Dangerous flows over low-water crossings. Water over
roadways. River or stream flows are elevated.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 407 AM AST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to
thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream
flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen.
- Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected
over the area. This additional rain will result in minor
flooding.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Guayanilla, PR; Penuelas, PR; Yauco, PR

Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:30 PM EDT Friday the stage was 3.2 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:30 PM EDT Friday was 3.3 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 3.2 feet.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 11:02AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
description:
A pair of light disturbances will impact the Interior, bringing
light snowfall throughout the evening tonight through the weekend.
Accumulations of 1-3 inches of snow are expected through this
weekend with higher amounts in higher elevations and areas near
Healy.

Due to the colder temperatures setting in, this could bring our
first permanent snowpack for some areas. Snowfall is expected to
accumulate on roadways, making travel conditions difficult at
times.
