headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 19 at 1:43PM PDT until October 21 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
description:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 20 to
25 feet. For the Beach Hazards Statement, a high risk of sneaker
waves.

* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.

* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 8 AM PDT Monday. For
the Beach Hazards Statement, from Tuesday morning through
Tuesday evening.

* IMPACTS...Large breaking waves will create hazardous conditions
along and within the surf zone, and could inundate beaches and
low lying shorelines. Beach erosion is possible, and exposed
infrastructure may be damaged. Sneaker waves can run up
significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over
rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of
their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters,
resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift
driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The highest breaking waves are expected
Sunday evening. Conditions may be just shy of high surf
advisory levels as surf builds to another peak late Tuesday
afternoon into Tuesday evening.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom
causing neck and back injuries.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 1 PM Sunday.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 8:43AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
description:
Light rain and snow is falling across portions of Southwest MT
this morning, including areas around Bozeman, Bozeman Pass on
Interstate 90, Big Sky, West Yellowstone, Norris Hill on Highway
287 and Raynolds Pass on Highway 87.

Rain and snow levels vary across Southwest MT at 830 AM, from
about 5500 feet to about 6500 feet. Some higher elevation
roadways, such as Raynolds Pass, Big Sky and the Bridger area do
have some snow and slush accumulation on roadways.

Expect the light precipitation to continue through late this
morning, before beginning to diminish.

Those traveling across Southwest MT should be alert for quickly
changing road conditions and areas of poor driving visibility.
areaDesc: Big Belt, Bridger and Castle Mountains; Madison River Valley; Gallatin Valley; Gallatin and Madison County Mountains and Centennial Mountains

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 19 at 2:38PM MDT by NWS Pocatello ID
description:
A very strong cold front is moving through the Snake River Plain
this afternoon. Expect a sudden wind shift with gusts approaching
or exceeding 50 mph. Drivers should be aware of the potential for
sudden strong crosswinds especially along Interstate 15. The winds
are expected to decrease somewhat by 6 pm MDT, but gusts 35 to 40
mph will be possible through the evening.
areaDesc: Upper Snake River Plain; Lower Snake River Plain; Marsh and Arbon Highlands; Blackfoot Mountains

headline: Hazardous Seas Warning issued October 20 at 8:12AM PDT until October 20 at 8:00AM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Rough bar conditions expected. Small Craft Advisory,
rough bar conditions expected with seas 10 to 13 ft at 11 to 12
seconds and southwest to west winds 5 to 10 kt. Seas and winds
will be highest Monday morning before lowering Monday afternoon.

* WHERE...In the Main Channel of the Columbia River Bar.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM PDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Conditions will be hazardous to small craft,
especially when operating near to, or attempting to cross, the
Columbia River Bar.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Ebb current of 5.48 kt at 450 PM Monday.
Seas 9 ft. Ebb current of 3.94 kt at 507 AM Tuesday. Seas 7 ft.
Strong ebb current of 5.63 kt at 523 PM Tuesday. Seas 13 to 16
ft.
areaDesc: Columbia River Bar

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 12:51AM PDT by NWS Elko NV
description:
Patchy fog has developed across portions of Humboldt and northern
Lander/Eureka counties this morning. Satellite imagery and remote
sensing platforms are depicting patchy fog with visibility
dropping to one mile or less in spots. Locations and roads being
affected are US Highway 95 from Winnemucca north to Paradise
Valley, I-80 from the Humboldt/Pershing county line east to Battle
Mountain, and Jungo road from Antelope Summit to Winnemucca.
Motorists are urged to use caution when driving along these and
other roadways as rapid changes to visibility are likely this
morning.

Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.
areaDesc: Humboldt County; Northern Lander County and Northern Eureka County

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 18 at 2:34PM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an
increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast
Counties.

* WHEN...Until 11 PM PDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

headline: Rip Current Statement issued October 20 at 4:43PM AST until October 22 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory and Coastal Flood Advisory,
large breaking waves of 10 to 14 feet. For the High Rip
Current Risk, life-threatening rip current.

* WHERE... For the High Surf Advisory, the most vulnerable areas
for high surf and beach erosion include Pinones along Road 187,
Parcelas Suarez, Villas del Mar, and Villa Christiana in Loiza;
Fortuna in Luquillo; Pueblo and Tamarindo in Aguadilla; Bario
Obrero, Pueblo and Jareaito in Arecibo; Las Boca in Barceloneta;
Machuca in Manati; Puerto Nuevo in Vega Baja; Ocean Park in San
Juan; and Barrio Espinal in Aguada. For the High Rip Current
Risk, beaches of northern Puerto Rico.

* WHEN...For the High Rip Current Risk now through late Tuesday
night. For the High Surf Advisory remains until 6 AM AST
Tuesday.

* IMPACTS...For the High Surf Advisory, high waves that can wash
over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks.
Rough surf may also knock you down. Large breaking waves will
result in localized beach/dune structure erosion and dangerous
swimming conditions. For the High Rip Current Risk, rip
currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into
deeper water, where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; North Central; Northwest; Mayaguez and Vicinity; Culebra; St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 4:11AM PDT until October 18 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.

* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South
Washington Coast.

* WHEN...For the first Beach Hazards Statement, from noon PDT
today through this afternoon. For the second Beach Hazards
Statement, from Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach
than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves
can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull
them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or
drowning.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when
sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in
the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water.
Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of
children and pets.

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 4:11AM PDT until October 17 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.

* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South
Washington Coast.

* WHEN...For the first Beach Hazards Statement, from noon PDT
today through this afternoon. For the second Beach Hazards
Statement, from Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach
than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves
can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull
them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or
drowning.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when
sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in
the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water.
Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of
children and pets.
areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 16 at 6:10PM CDT until October 16 at 6:45PM CDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
SVRGLD

The National Weather Service in Goodland has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Western Cheyenne County in northwestern Kansas...

* Until 645 PM CDT.

* At 609 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 5 miles east of
Bonny Reservoir, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and half dollar size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
St. Francis.
areaDesc: Cheyenne, KS

IN CENTRAL MISSOURI

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 20 at 3:38PM EDT until October 21 at 1:00PM EDT by NWS Northern Indiana
description:
* WHAT...For the Small Craft Advisory, southwest winds 15 to 25
knots with gusts up to 30 knots and waves 4 to 7 feet expected.

40 knots and waves 7 to 10 feet expected.

capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility.

Worthington, Knightsville, Lyons, Harmony, Fillmore, Switz City,

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 10:15AM PDT until October 19 at 12:00AM PDT by NWS Eureka CA
description:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves expected.

* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast,
Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening. .

* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach
without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks,
jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large
objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt; Mendocino Coast

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 11:58AM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves, and
strong longshore currents in the surf zone.

* WHERE...The beaches north of Cape Hatteras.

* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw
a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck
and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create
dangerous swimming conditions.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 11:30 AM Friday.
areaDesc: Northern Outer Banks; Hatteras Island

description:
Offshore waters forecast for the Gulf of Alaska West of 144W

Wind forecasts reflect the predominant speed and direction
expected. Sea forecasts represent an average of the highest
one-third of the combined wind wave and swell height.

.TODAY...SW wind 30 to 40 kt. Seas 23 to 30 ft.
.TONIGHT...W wind 25 to 35 kt. Seas 16 to 23 ft.
.FRI...SW wind 10 to 25 kt. Seas 9 to 17 ft.
.FRI NIGHT...N wind 10 to 25 kt. Seas 6 to 10 ft.
.SAT...NW wind 15 to 30 kt. Seas 9 to 17 ft.
.SUN...S wind 20 to 35 kt. Seas 9 to 17 ft.
.MON...W wind 20 to 35 kt. Seas 17 to 32 ft.
areaDesc: Gulf of Alaska Offshore South of 57N North of 55N and West of 144W

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 17 at 4:26PM EDT until October 18 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
description:
* WHAT...Northeast to east winds near 20 knots, with seas up to 7
feet in the Straits of Florida.

* WHERE...Straits of Florida, Hawk Channel, Gulf waters
including the Dry Tortugas, and Florida Bay.

* WHEN...In Effect.

* IMPACTS...A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20
to 33 knots, or seas of 7 feet or greater, are expected to
produce hazardous conditions for small craft. These hazardous
conditions may result in poor vessel handling and steering
response, broaching, overturned dinghies and kayaks, slips and
falls on slippery decks, rub damage along docks and seawalls,
swamped bows at reef tract mooring balls, and dragging anchors.
areaDesc: Florida Bay including Barnes Sound, Blackwater Sound, and Buttonwood Sound; Bayside and Gulfside from Craig Key to West End of Seven Mile Bridge; Gulf of America from East Cape Sable to Chokoloskee 20 to 60 NM out and beyond 5 fathoms; Gulf of America including Dry Tortugas and Rebecca Shoal Channel; Gulf of America from West End of Seven Mile Bridge to Halfmoon Shoal out to 5 Fathoms; Hawk Channel from Ocean Reef to Craig Key out to the reef; Hawk Channel from Craig Key to west end of Seven Mile Bridge out to the reef; Hawk Channel from west end of Seven Mile Bridge to Halfmoon Shoal out to the reef; Straits of Florida from Ocean Reef to Craig Key out 20 NM; Straits of Florida from Craig Key to west end of Seven Mile Bridge out 20 NM; Straits of Florida from west end of Seven Mile Bridge to south of Halfmoon Shoal out 20 NM; Straits of Florida from Halfmoon Shoal to 20 NM west of Dry Tortugas out 20 NM; Straits of Florida from Ocean Reef to Craig Key 20 to 60 NM out; Straits of Florida from Craig Key to west end of Seven Mile Bridge 20 to 60 NM out; Straits of Florida from west end of Seven Mile Bridge to south of Halfmoon Shoal 20 to 60 NM out; Straits of Florida from Halfmoon Shoal to 20 NM west of Dry Tortugas 20 to 60 NM out

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 18 at 3:40PM CDT until October 18 at 4:30PM CDT by NWS Little Rock AR
description:
SVRLZK

The National Weather Service in Little Rock has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Northeastern Clark County in southwestern Arkansas...
Southwestern Grant County in central Arkansas...
Northwestern Dallas County in southwestern Arkansas...
Eastern Hot Spring County in southwestern Arkansas...

* Until 430 PM CDT.

* At 339 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Caddo Valley,
or near Arkadelphia, moving northeast at 55 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Arkadelphia...                    Malvern...
Rockport...                       Caddo Valley...
Perla...                          Donaldson...
Friendship...                     Magnet Cove...
Lono...                           Lower Lake Recreation Area...
Social Hill...                    Joan...
Brush Creek...                    Griffithtown...
Midway in Hot Spring County...    Lake Catherine State Park...
areaDesc: Clark, AR; Dallas, AR; Grant, AR; Hot Spring, AR

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 8:42PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
description:

Camp Creek Lake, or 18 miles northeast of Hearne, moving southeast at
35 mph.

HAZARD...Winds in excess of 30 mph and nickel size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is
possible.

This strong thunderstorm will be near...
Camp Creek Lake around 845 PM CDT.

Other locations impacted by this storm include Easterly, Normangee,
Hilltop Lakes, New Baden, and Ridge.

headline: Gale Warning issued October 18 at 3:07PM AKDT until October 20 at 5:00AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
description:
Coastal Waters Forecast for Southwest Alaska+Bristol Bay+The
Alaska Peninsula Waters and the Aleutian Islands up to 100 nm out.

Wind forecasts reflect the predominant speed and direction
expected. Sea forecasts represent an average of the highest
one-third of the combined wind wave and swell height.

.TONIGHT...NW wind 20 kt becoming SE after midnight. Seas 4 ft.
.SUN...NE wind 35 kt. Seas 6 ft building to 11 ft in the
afternoon. Rain.
.SUN NIGHT...N wind 35 kt. Seas 15 ft. Rain.
.MON...NW wind 20 kt. Seas 10 ft.
.MON NIGHT...NW wind 15 kt. Seas 5 ft.
.TUE...NW wind 30 kt. Seas 6 ft.
.WED THROUGH THU...NW wind 40 kt. Seas 8 ft.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 7:51PM CDT by NWS Tulsa OK
description:
At 751 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated strong thunderstorms along a
line extending from 6 miles south of Okfuskee to 2 miles west of
Cromwell. Movement was southeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and nickel size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down small tree limbs and blow
around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation
is possible.

Locations in or near the path include...
Bryant...                         Henryetta...
Clearview...                      Weleetka...
Okemah...                         Bearden...
Pharoah...

This includes Interstate 40 in Oklahoma between mile markers 212 and

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 1:40PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
description:
Additional waves of energy moving up the Bering Strait will bring
the potential for snow squalls Saturday night through Sunday.
Squalls are notoriously quick in nature, but can bring brief heavy
bursts of snow and wind gusts up to 35 mph which can reduce
visibility below 1 mile at times. Snow accumulations of 4 to 8
inches is possible over Saint Lawrence Island, with 1 to 4 inches
falling over the Western Seward Peninsula between Teller and
Wales.
areaDesc: Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; St Lawrence Island

headline: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 16 at 10:21AM EDT until October 17 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
description:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.

* WHERE...Florida Keys.

* WHEN...Through late tonight.

* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets
and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some
seawalls and docks will be overtopped. In the Lower and Middle
Keys, minor flooding will be most pronounced around the time
of high tide. In the Upper Keys, little relief is expected,
even outside the windows of high tide. Boaters can expect less
clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that
persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost
certain to contain a mix of saltwater.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

description:

* WHERE...Niihau and Kauai.

* WHEN...Until noon HST today.

* IMPACTS...Flood prone roads and other low lying areas may be
closed due to elevated runoff and overflowing streams. Urban areas
may receive more significant flooding and property damage due to

early this morning. This system will move over Kauai County

rainfall that may lead to flooding in some areas.

headline: Flash Flood Warning issued October 18 at 6:36PM CDT until October 18 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Little Rock AR
description:
FFWLZK

The National Weather Service in Little Rock has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
East Central Lawrence County in eastern Arkansas...

* Until 800 PM CDT.

* At 636 PM CDT, Emergency Management reported flooded roadways
within Walnut Ridge. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen.
Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are possible in the
warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin
shortly.

HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.

SOURCE...Emergency management reported.

IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban
areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as
other poor drainage and low-lying areas.

* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...
Walnut Ridge...                    Hoxie...
Dicus...
areaDesc: Lawrence, AR

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 12:36PM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an
increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay, Southern Monterey Bay, and Big Sur Coast.

* WHEN...From 8 PM PDT this evening through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

description:

headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 19 at 1:20PM MDT until October 20 at 12:00PM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
description:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow as a result of strong winds are
expected. Total snow accumulations 6 to 10 inches, mainly above
8000 feet. Winds gusting as high as 60 mph. Locally stronger winds
around Chief Joseph Hwy 60 to 70 mph are expected through Sunday
evening.

* WHERE...Absaroka Mountains and Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains.

* WHEN...Until Noon MDT Monday. Greatest impacts will occur
overnight.

* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions, especially over
mountain passes. Travel across Togwotee Pass could be particularly
difficult due to strong winds and falling snow. Occasional near
white-out conditions are possible.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Strongest winds will occur during the day
Sunday through Sunday evening. Snow will begin later Sunday
afternoon, generally after 6 PM. The combination of wind and snow
will be the primary threat with this event.
areaDesc: Absaroka Mountains; Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 19 at 12:15PM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
description:
A Pacific cold front is current moving through the western
portions of Southwest MT at 1215 PM. Expect rain to change to snow
at higher elevations early this afternoon.

The snow could reduce visibility below a half mile at times, along
with making some roadways slippery.

Those traveling around Wise River, Wisdom or Chief Joseph Pass
should be alert for quickly changing road conditions this
afternoon.
areaDesc: Northwest Beaverhead County

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 19 at 9:28PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
description:

extending from 15 miles northeast of Monroe to 7 miles north of
Lancaster. Movement was east at 50 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects.

Locations impacted include...
Monroe, Unionville, Wesley Chapel, Wingate, Waxhaw, Marshville,
Mineral Springs, Sturdivants, Fairview In Union County, and Indian
Trail.
areaDesc: Union

headline: Marine Weather Statement issued October 17 at 1:50PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
At 146 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated strong thunderstorms,
capable of producing winds to around 30 knots. These
thunderstorms were located over mainly areas of the Caribbean, Mona
Passage and the nearshore northern waters, moving northeast at 15
to 20 knots. Development of additional t-storms over the waters
is expected along with movement of current t-storms over the
offshore Atlantic Waters.
areaDesc: Atlantic Waters of Puerto Rico AND USVI from 10 NM to 19.5N; Coastal Waters of Northern Puerto Rico out 10 NM; Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico from 10 NM to 17N, including the Coastal Waters of Saint Croix; Coastal Waters of Southern Puerto Rico out 10 NM; Mona Passage Southward to 17N; Coastal Waters OF Northwestern Puerto Rico out 10 NM; Coastal Waters OF Southwestern Puerto Rico out 10 NM

headline: Special Marine Warning issued October 16 at 4:37PM CDT until October 16 at 5:00PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
description:
SMWHGX

The National Weather Service in League City has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Coastal waters from High Island to Freeport TX out 20 NM...
Galveston Bay...

* Until 500 PM CDT.

* At 436 PM CDT, a shower producing waterspouts was located near
Offatts Bayou, or 7 nm south of Galveston Pier 21, moving northwest
at 5 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts.

SOURCE...Emergency management.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can create locally hazardous seas.

* Locations impacted include...
Galveston Causeway, Offatts Bayou, Galveston Ship Channel, and
northeastern West Bay.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 20 at 5:09PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
description:
.Multiple rounds of heavy rain are possible for the panhandle this
week as a parade of systems move over the area. Locations primarily
impacted with the highest rain rates are expected to be the southern
half of the panhandle. The next system, arriving Tuesday, has a 60%
chance for rain rates to exceed one tenth of an inch per hour for 24
hours. Coinciding with the high wind gusts is a 30% chance for rain
rates to exceed 0.2 inches per hour. Rain totals have an 80% chance
to be between 1.5 and 3.5 inches. The third system late in the week
has lower confidence but higher potential, with totals between 1.5
and 4.5 inches. No flooding is currently expected, but it is
possible that rivers and streams will rapidly rise with each round
of precipitation.
areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

headline: The Beach Hazards Statement has been cancelled.
description: The Beach Hazards Statement has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
areaDesc: Hatteras Island

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 3:47AM EDT until October 16 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
description:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to 1 to 2 feet of
inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines
and tidal waterways. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous
rip currents, large breaking waves expected, and strong
longshore currents in the surf zone.

* WHERE...Hatteras Island.

* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 8 PM EDT Friday.
For the Beach Hazards Statement, from 8 AM EDT this morning
through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is
possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways
resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low
lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes
adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding.
Portions of NC-12 may be impacted with ocean overwash around
high tide. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a
swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and
back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous
swimming conditions.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 10:30 AM Thursday.
areaDesc: Hatteras Island

headline: Special Marine Warning issued October 16 at 9:19PM AST until October 16 at 10:15PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
SMWSJU

The National Weather Service in San Juan has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Atlantic Waters of Puerto Rico AND USVI from 10 NM to 19.5N...

* Until 1015 PM AST.

* At 917 PM AST, a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing
waterspouts was located over mainly areas of offshore Atlantic
Waters, moving southeast at 15 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts to 40 knots.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally
hazardous seas. Small craft could be damaged in briefly
higher winds and suddenly higher waves.

* The severe thunderstorm will remain over mainly open waters.
areaDesc: Atlantic Waters of Puerto Rico AND USVI from 10 NM to 19.5N

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 4:43AM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an
increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast
Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 20 at 2:57PM PDT until October 21 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
description:
* WHAT...A high risk of sneaker waves.

* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.

* WHEN...From Tuesday morning through Tuesday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on
beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These
waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly
pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious
injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping
anyone caught underneath.


* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

headline: Coastal Flood Warning issued October 18 at 6:40PM EDT until October 19 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
description:
* WHAT...Up to one foot of inundation above ground level in low
lying areas due to tidal flooding.

* WHERE...Shoreline in Anne Arundel County.

* WHEN...For the first Coastal Flood Advisory, until 2 PM EDT
Sunday, especially around the time of high tide. For the Coastal
Flood Warning, from 2 PM to 8 PM EDT Sunday. For the second
Coastal Flood Advisory, from 8 PM Sunday to 8 AM EDT Monday,
especially around the time of high tide.

* IMPACTS...At 3.5 feet, water reaches the floor of the Maritime
Museum in Annapolis, begins to cover Bowyer Road on the Naval
Academy campus, and numerous businesses on Dock Street are
flooded, along with the City Dock parking lot. Bayside Beach
begins to flood around Harbor Rd and Lake Dr.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides two to two and a half feet above
normal. The next high tides at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy are
4:25 AM and 5:02 PM.
areaDesc: Anne Arundel

* WHERE...Shoreline in Anne Arundel County.

* WHEN...For the first Coastal Flood Advisory, until 2 PM EDT
Sunday, especially around the time of high tide. For the Coastal
Flood Warning, from 2 PM to 8 PM EDT Sunday. For the second
Coastal Flood Advisory, from 8 PM Sunday to 8 AM EDT Monday,
especially around the time of high tide.

* IMPACTS...At 3.5 feet, water reaches the floor of the Maritime
Museum in Annapolis, begins to cover Bowyer Road on the Naval
Academy campus, and numerous businesses on Dock Street are
flooded, along with the City Dock parking lot. Bayside Beach
begins to flood around Harbor Rd and Lake Dr.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides two to two and a half feet above
normal. The next high tides at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy are
4:25 AM and 5:02 PM.
areaDesc: Anne Arundel

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 12:22AM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
description:

expect rapidly changing visibility, down to near zero at times.

provide plenty of braking distance between yourself and any
vehicles in front of you.

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 1:59PM PDT until October 19 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.

* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South
Washington Coast.

* WHEN...For the first Beach Hazards Statement, from this
afternoon through Saturday evening. For the second Beach
Hazards Statement, from Sunday afternoon through Sunday evening.

* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach
than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves
can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull
them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or
drowning.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when
sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in
the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water.
Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of
children and pets.
areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast
